{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14374,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Satyrium odorum, a type of orchid, requires careful watering to thrive. During the growing season, water the plant thoroughly but allow the soil to dry out between waterings. This mimics the natural environment of the plant, which experiences dry periods. Generally, water the plant once every 7-10 days, although this may vary depending on the climate and potting medium. In the dormant season, reduce watering significantly to prevent root rot, keeping the soil slightly moist rather than wet. It's important to use water that is free from salts and chemicals, so use distilled or rainwater if possible."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Satyrium odorum thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It should be placed in a location where it can receive plenty of light without being exposed to direct sun rays, which can scorch the leaves and flowers. Aim for at least 6-8 hours of filtered sunlight or dappled shade daily. If grown indoors, placing it near an east-facing window can provide the plant with sufficient light while protecting it from harsher midday sun. During the winter months, when natural light is less intense, consider supplementing with a grow light to ensure it gets adequate light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is minimal for Satyrium odorum, but it helps keep the plant healthy and encourages new growth. Remove any dead or yellowing leaves with clean, sharp scissors to prevent disease spread. After the flowering period, cut back spent flower spikes to the base to conserve energy. Be cautious not to damage any new growth or shoots in the process, as these will be important for the plant's subsequent growth cycles. Regularly cleaning up any plant debris around your Satyrium odorum also helps maintain its health and vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Scented Orchid","description":"Satyrium odorum is a species of orchid endemic to southwestern Cape Province.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Scented Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Satyrium odorum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14872,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Daphne odora prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. It is crucial to avoid waterlogging as this plant is susceptible to root rot. Water the plant once the top inch of soil feels dry. During hot and dry weather, increase watering frequency, yet ensure that excess water can drain to prevent standing water. In winter, cut back on watering as growth slows down. Always check the soil moisture before watering, as overwatering is one of the most common causes of plant failure. Mulching can help retain moisture and stabilize soil temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Daphne odora thrives best in partial to full shade conditions but can tolerate morning sun. Ensure the plant is protected from harsh midday and afternoon sun, as this can scorch the leaves and cause stress. In hotter regions, providing dappled or filtered shade throughout the day will help keep the plant healthy. If planted indoors, place it near a window with indirect sunlight. The balance of adequate light without excessive heat will contribute to optimal growth and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Daphne odora is not always necessary, but light pruning can help maintain its shape and encourage bushiness. The best time to prune is after flowering, usually in spring. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems to prevent infection and to encourage healthy growth. If necessary, lightly trim back longer stems to keep a neat shape. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant and reduce flowering. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and minimize damage to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Winter daphne","description":"Daphne odora (winter daphne) is a species of flowering plant in the family Thymelaeaceae, native to China, later spread to Japan and Korea. It is an evergreen shrub, grown for its very fragrant, fleshy, pale-pink, tubular flowers, each with 4 spreading lobes, and for its glossy foliage. It rarely fruits, producing red berries after flowering.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Japan","Korea"],"other_name":["Winter daphne"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Daphne odora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15069,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ulmus crassifolia, commonly known as cedar elm, prefers moderate watering. It's a drought-tolerant tree once established, so water it regularly in its early years to ensure proper root development. Typically, watering once a week during dry periods is sufficient. When watering, ensure the soil is moist but not waterlogged, as overly wet conditions can lead to root rot. Reduce watering frequency during wet seasons or when the tree is mature and has a well-established root system, as it will naturally draw moisture from deeper soil levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cedar elms thrive in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. While they can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure promotes denser foliage and better overall health. In hot climates, ensure the tree has access to ample water to compensate for the intense sun and heat, which can cause stress if soil moisture is insufficient. Planting in a location with unobstructed sunlight will give the best results, and ensure the surrounding area provides enough space for its mature height and spread."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Ulmus crassifolia should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on removing dead or diseased branches to maintain overall tree health. Thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration. Avoid excessive pruning, which can stress the tree and lead to poor growth. When pruning, make clean cuts just outside of the branch collar to facilitate proper healing. This elm generally has a vase-shaped growth habit, so minimal shaping may be required unless space is limited or specific aesthetic forms are desired."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cedar Elm","description":"Ulmus crassifolia Nutt., the Texas cedar elm or simply cedar elm, is a deciduous tree native to south central North America, mainly in southern and eastern Texas, southern Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana, with small populations in western Mississippi, southwest Tennessee and north central Florida; it also occurs in northeastern Mexico. It is the most common elm tree in Texas. The tree typically grows well in flat valley bottom areas referred to as 'Cedar Elm Flats'. The...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Cedar Elm"],"pest_susceptibility":["Elm Leaf Beetle","Dutch Elm Disease"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Ulmus crassifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14575,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Paspalum setaceum, commonly known as thin paspalum, is a grass species that thrives in moist to well-drained soils. While it is relatively drought-tolerant once established, regular watering will encourage lush growth, particularly in hot, dry periods. Ideally, water this plant weekly, soaking the soil deeply to ensure the roots have access to moisture. Be careful to avoid overwatering, as standing water can lead to root rot. During cooler months, reduce watering frequency as the plant's growth rate slows. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Paspalum setaceum performs best in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal growth, provide at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate some shade, areas with too much shade can lead to sparse growth and reduced vigor. However, in regions with particularly intense sunlight, providing some afternoon shade can help to prevent the grass from becoming stressed. Positioning it in a location that receives morning sun and afternoon shade could strike a beneficial balance. Adjust the sunlight exposure based on your local climate and the specific growth response you observe."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Paspalum setaceum focuses primarily on maintaining its desired shape and promoting healthy growth. Regularly mow or trim the foliage to encourage denser growth and to prevent the plant from becoming too leggy. Mid to late spring is an ideal time for a more thorough cut back if the grass has grown excessively tall. Remove any dead or damaged leaves to maintain the plant’s aesthetic appeal and overall health. This also helps prevent diseases and allows for better air circulation. Regular mowing or trimming will also help control the spread of this plant, keeping it from overtaking other areas."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Thin Paspalum","description":"Paspalum setaceum is a species of grass known by several common names, including thin paspalum. It is native to the Americas, where it can be found in the eastern and central United States, Ontario in Canada, Mexico, Central America, and the Caribbean. It can be found in other areas of the world as an introduced, and often invasive, species, including many Pacific Islands. It is a weed of lawns and turf.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Thin Paspalum"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Paspalum setaceum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During hot and dry periods, the plant may need watering more frequently. However, ensure proper drainage to avoid standing water, as overly wet conditions can harm the plant roots. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering, especially in hotter climates."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia splendens prefers full sun conditions to thrive, meaning it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure encourages optimal flower production and growth. In regions with hot climates, providing light afternoon shade can help prevent wilting or scorching. If grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window or another sunny spot to ensure it receives enough light. Ensuring the plant has adequate sunlight is crucial for maintaining vibrant blooms and healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia splendens encourages bushier growth and prolongs flowering. To prune, pinch back the tips when the plant is young, which helps foster a more compact and full appearance. Deadheading spent blooms is also important and should be done regularly to stimulate continued blooming throughout the season. Additionally, cutting back the plant by about one-third after the initial flowering phase can promote a second bloom. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent disease spread during the pruning process."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Scarlet Sage","description":"Salvia splendens, the scarlet sage or tropical sage, is a tender herbaceous perennial native to Brazil, growing at 2,000 to 3,000 m (6,600 to 9,800 ft) elevation where it is warm year-round and with high humidity. The native plant, rarely seen in cultivation, reaches 1.3 m (4.3 ft) tall. It is crucial to allow the topsoil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, particularly in areas with higher humidity or rainfall. Consistently overwatering can harm the plant, so observe local climate conditions to adjust the watering schedule accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chamaecrista fasciculata thrives in full sun conditions, requiring exposure to at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. The plant's ability to tolerate high heat and direct sun makes it well-suited for sunny, open landscapes."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Chamaecrista fasciculata is generally minimal. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15565,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Juniperus ashei, commonly known as Ashe's juniper or mountain cedar, is highly drought-tolerant and requires minimal watering once established. It's crucial to water young plants deeply but infrequently to help them develop a strong root system. Mature plants rarely need supplemental watering except during prolonged dry spells or extreme heat conditions. Overwatering can lead to root rot and should be avoided. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging. During periods of normal rainfall, additional watering is typically unnecessary for this adaptable plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ashe's juniper thrives in full sun environments. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to maintain its dense foliage and healthy growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight can lead to sparse growth and a weak structure. Choose a location with full sun exposure for the best results. In extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade may help reduce stress, but generally, maximum sunlight will encourage the strongest development and optimal health for Juniperus ashei."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Juniperus ashei should be done minimally, primarily to maintain its shape or to remove dead or diseased branches. The best time for pruning is late winter to early spring, just before the new growth phase begins. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to avoid tearing the bark, and avoid cutting into old wood that won't regenerate. Regularly remove any shoots or branches growing inward or overlapping to maintain good air circulation and prevent disease. Over-pruning can stress the plant, so only light trimming is recommended."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Ashe juniper","description":"Juniperus ashei (Ashe juniper, post cedar, mountain cedar, or blueberry juniper) is a drought-tolerant evergreen tree, native to northeastern Mexico and the south-central United States north to southern Missouri; the largest areas are in central Texas, where extensive stands occur. It grows up to 10 metres (33 ft) tall, rarely 15 metres (49 ft), and provides erosion control and year-round shade for wildlife and livestock.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue-grey\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Ashe juniper"],"pest_susceptibility":["Cedar-apple rust","Bagworms"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Juniperus ashei"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15768,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mertensia paniculata, commonly known as Tall Bluebells or Northern Bluebells, thrives in consistently moist soil conditions. It’s important to keep the soil evenly damp but not waterlogged, as excessive water can lead to root rot. During its active growing season in spring and summer, it may require regular watering, particularly in dry spells, to maintain its moisture needs. In contrast, you should reduce watering in the fall and winter when the plant becomes dormant, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature fluctuations."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mertensia paniculata performs best in partial to full shade, making it ideal for woodland garden settings or shaded areas. It prefers a cooler environment, which can be challenging in regions with intense heat; hence, protection from harsh midday sun is crucial. In regions with colder climates, it can tolerate more sunlight, provided it is balanced with adequate moisture. Placing it in a location with morning sun and afternoon shade often yields the best results. Avoid full sun exposure, as this can lead to leaf scorch and stunted growth, especially if the soil dries out too quickly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mertensia paniculata is generally minimal and mostly consists of deadheading to encourage continued blooming throughout its flowering period. Once the flowers have faded, you can trim the spent flower spikes back to the base to prevent self-seeding and maintain a tidy appearance. After the blooming season is over, cut back any yellowing or dead foliage to the ground as the plant enters dormancy. This will not only tidy up the garden but also prevent any potential for disease to overwinter. It's important to use clean and sharp pruning tools to prevent any damage to the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Tall Bluebell","description":"Mertensia paniculata, also known as the tall lungwort, tall bluebells, or northern bluebells, is an herb or dwarf shrub with drooping bright-blue, bell-shaped flowers. It is native to northwestern North America and the Great Lakes.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Tall Bluebell"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Mertensia paniculata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15669,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Syngonium podophyllum, commonly known as the arrowhead plant, prefers evenly moist soil but should never be waterlogged. Water the plant when the top inch of soil dries out. During the growing season in spring and summer, more frequent watering may be necessary. Reduce watering during fall and winter when the plant's growth slows. It's beneficial to ensure proper drainage to prevent root rot, so using a pot with drainage holes and a well-draining potting mix is recommended. Mist the leaves occasionally, especially in dry indoor environments, to maintain humidity."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Syngonium podophyllum thrives in bright, indirect light but can adapt to lower light conditions. Avoid direct sunlight as it can scorch the leaves. A location near a north or east-facing window is ideal to provide softer lighting conditions. If placed in a lower light environment, the plant may grow more slowly, and the leaves may have less variegation. Using sheer curtains to diffuse direct sunlight or placing the plant a few feet away from a south or west-facing window can help prevent any leaf burn from direct sun exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Syngonium podophyllum helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. Regularly remove any yellow, dead, or damaged leaves to keep the plant looking tidy. Pruning can also control its vining tendency; trim the long stems back to a leaf node to encourage lateral growth and a fuller appearance. This can be done year-round, but the best time is in the spring or early summer when the plant is actively growing. Wear gloves or wash hands after pruning, as the plant's sap can be an irritant to some people."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Goosefoot-plant","description":"Syngonium podophyllum is a species of aroid, and commonly cultivated as a houseplant. The species is native to a wide region of Latin America from Mexico to Bolivia, and naturalized in the West Indies, Florida, Texas, Hawaii, and other places.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America","West Indies","Bolivia"],"other_name":["Goosefoot-plant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Stem Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Syngonium podophyllum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14180,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sticta limbata is a type of lichen commonly found in humid forested areas. As it is not a typical houseplant, direct care instructions are rare. However, if one attempts to cultivate lichen, it requires a microhabitat that mimics its natural environment. This means maintaining high humidity, often achieved through frequent misting rather than traditional watering, to simulate the moist air of its typical tropical habitat. Avoid over-wetting, as standing water can lead to decay. Monitoring local temperatures and ensuring good air circulation while keeping moisture levels up will help in successful cultivation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sticta limbata, being a lichen, requires filtered light similar to the dappled sunlight it would receive in a forest environment. Direct sunlight can be harmful, leading to desiccation and damage. Instead, provide indirect light or place under a shaded area where it can receive diffused light throughout the day. If cultivating indoors, a spot near a north or east-facing window, where it gets sufficient light without harsh direct sunlight, is ideal. Balancing light exposure with humidity is crucial to its health, replicating the cool, shaded conditions of its native habitat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to lichens such as Sticta limbata in the traditional sense experienced with vascular plants. Instead, cultivation involves ensuring optimal conditions rather than shaping the organism through cutting. If necessary, removal of small sections can be done to prevent stress, such as trimming a lichen's edges if they grow into an undesirable area, or if certain parts start to deteriorate. This should be done carefully and sparingly to avoid damaging the organism. It's best to simulate natural conditions which inherently contain means for regulating growth and removal of dead parts."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Powdered Moon Lichen","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Tropical and subtropical regions"],"other_name":["Powdered Moon Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Sticta limbata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14975,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phlebodium aureum prefers to have its soil consistently moist, but not waterlogged. Water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. Be cautious about overwatering as this can lead to root rot. Ideally, use lukewarm water and water thoroughly until it drains through the pot's bottom holes. During its growing season in spring and summer, you may need to water more frequently, while in the dormant fall and winter months, watering can be reduced. Always consider the humidity of your environment as Phlebodium aureum thrives in higher humidity."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phlebodium aureum thrives best in indirect light, making it an excellent choice for indoor environments. It prefers medium to bright light but should be kept away from direct sunlight, which can scorch its delicate fronds. If the light is too low, the plant may not grow as robustly, so try to place it near an east or north-facing window, where it can receive filtered sunlight. In situations where natural light is insufficient, consider using fluorescent lights to supplement its light needs. Keep an eye on the fronds to ensure they remain vibrant, adjusting the light exposure accordingly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phlebodium aureum is generally minimal and primarily involves removing dead or damaged fronds to maintain plant health and appearance. Inspect the plant regularly for any brown, yellow, or damaged fronds, and cut these off at the base using sharp, sterilized scissors to prevent any potential spread of disease. This not only keeps the plant looking tidy but also encourages new growth. Avoid cutting healthy fronds and only prune when necessary. Regularly cleaning the plant from dust by gently wiping the fronds can also improve its overall health and vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"golden polypody","description":"Phlebodium aureum (golden polypody, golden serpent fern, cabbage palm fern, gold-foot fern, hare-foot fern; syn. Polypodium aureum, Polypodium leucotomos) is an epiphytic fern native to tropical and subtropical regions of the Americas. It is confined to the eastern side of the continents, extending north into the United States to Florida and the extreme southeast of Georgia, and south through the Caribbean (the Bahamas, Puerto Rico, and Lesser Antilles), and northern and eastern South America to Paraguay....","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Tropical Americas","Caribbean"],"other_name":["golden polypody"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects","Aphids"],"propagation":["Rhizome division"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Phlebodium aureum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15173,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Coreopsis major prefers moderate watering. It is drought-tolerant once established, meaning it can withstand dry spells without needing frequent watering. However, for optimal growth and flowering, ensure the plant receives water during prolonged periods of dry weather. When watering, it's best to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to ensure the plant isn’t left in overly moist conditions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so always make sure the soil has good drainage. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture in the soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coreopsis major thrives in full sun, needing at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal flowering. While it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade can result in fewer flowers and leggy growth. In regions with extremely hot summers, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense heat, but generally, more sun exposure equates to a better display of blooms. Ensure the site you choose is open and receives ample sunlight to support healthy growth and vibrant flower production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Coreopsis major will encourage continued blooming and maintain a tidy appearance. After the initial flowering, spent blooms should be deadheaded regularly to promote further blossoming. At the end of the blooming season, cut back the stems to about a third of their original height to prepare the plant for the next growing season. In early spring, check for any dead or damaged stems and remove them to encourage new growth. This keeps the plant healthy and vigorous, ensuring it returns with a robust display of flowers each year."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Greater Tickseed","description":"Coreopsis major is a North American species of tickseeds, in the sunflower family. It is native to the eastern United States, from Louisiana to Virginia and as far inland as Indiana and Ohio. There are isolated populations in Pennsylvania, Long Island, and Massachusetts, most likely escapes from cultivation.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Greater Tickseed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Dividing Rhizomes"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Coreopsis major"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15867,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sedum oxypetalum is a succulent, which means it stores water in its leaves and requires less frequent watering than other plants. It is crucial to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. In general, watering every two to three weeks is sufficient, but this can vary depending on the climate and the potting medium. During the winter months, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows, and it enters a dormant period. Always use a well-draining soil mix to prevent water from sitting around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sedum oxypetalum thrives in full sun, which helps to keep its compact form and vibrant color. Ideally, this plant requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. If growing indoors, place the sedum near a south or west-facing window to ensure it receives adequate light. In less sunny locations, such as northern regions, the plant may become leggy as it stretches towards the light. For best results, provide additional light with a grow light if necessary to maintain its structure and health. Outdoor plants should be positioned in a sunny location, avoiding full shade."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sedum oxypetalum helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. The best time to prune is in spring or early summer when the plant is actively growing. Gently pinch off or use clean, sharp scissors to remove any leggy, dead, or damaged stems. If the plant becomes too tall, cutting back some of the longer stems can promote bushier growth. Regular pruning also helps to remove any flower stalks after blooming to prevent the plant from getting leggy. Always wear gloves when pruning, as some sedums can cause skin irritation."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Dwarf Tree Stonecrop","description":"Sedum oxypetalum, the dwarf tree stonecrop, is a species of flowering plant in the family Crassulaceae, native to Mexico. A semi-woody succulent shrub reaching 0.6 m (2 ft), it has a tree-like growth form.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Dwarf Tree Stonecrop"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mealybugs","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Sedum oxypetalum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15965,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Heimia salicifolia, commonly known as \"Sinicuichi,\" prefers consistently moist soils. It is best to water this plant regularly to keep the soil evenly damp, particularly during its active growing season in spring and summer. However, be cautious not to overwater, as this could lead to root rot. In cooler seasons or dormant periods, reduce the frequency of watering, allowing the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Utilizing well-draining soil can help prevent excess moisture retention and protect the roots from rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Heimia salicifolia thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, provide this plant with at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to stimulate healthy growth and flowering. If grown indoors or in a shady spot, ensure that it receives bright, indirect light to keep it healthy. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to protect it from leaf scorch. When growing this plant outdoors, position it in a location that receives ample sunlight throughout the day to mimic its natural habitat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Heimia salicifolia involves removing dead or damaged stems to promote healthier growth and maintain the plant's shape. It is best done during late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make precise cuts, encouraging vigorous new growth. Prune back branches to a node or where they meet another branch to ensure proper regrowth. Regular pruning can also help improve air circulation within the plant, reducing the risk of fungal diseases and keeping the plant looking its best."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"sun opener","description":"Heimia salicifolia is a species of flowering plant in the Loosestrife family, Lythraceae. It is native to the Americas, ranging from the southwestern United States (Texas and New Mexico) through Mexico and Central America to Argentina. Common names include shrubby yellowcrest, sinicuichi, sun opener, willow-leaf heimia, sini. The plant has been used for shamanic purposes by native peoples in Central America and Mexico.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","South America"],"other_name":["sun opener"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Anthracnose"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Heimia salicifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is important to let the topsoil dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, as this plant dislikes being overwatered. During the growing season, water more frequently to support growth, but in the dormant winter months, reduce watering to allow the plant some rest. Ensure that the plant is in well-draining soil and the pot has drainage holes. Overwatering is one of the main issues for Cissus trifoliata, so it’s better to err on the side of underwatering rather than overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cissus trifoliata thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially if it is the gentle morning or late afternoon sun, but intense midday sun should be avoided as it can scorch the leaves. If the plant is kept indoors, place it near a window where it can receive ample light throughout the day. While it can endure lower light conditions, its growth may slow, and it might become leggy. Therefore, ensuring it receives enough light will help keep it healthy and promote robust growth. Adjust its position seasonally if necessary to maximize light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cissus trifoliata is crucial to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is during the growing season, typically spring and summer. Trim back any leggy, dead, or damaged vines using clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears. You can also pinch back young growth to encourage bushiness. Regular pruning helps prevent the plant from becoming too untidy or overgrown. Be careful not to remove more than a third of the plant at a time, as excessive pruning can stress the plant. Always sanitize your tools before and after to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"sorrelvine","description":"Cissus trifoliata, known variously as possum-grape, sorrelvine, or vine-sorrel, is a New World plant species in the grape family. It is also dispersed among some islands in the Caribbean (Aruba, Bahamas, Cuba, Hispaniola, Jamaica, Puerto...","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["sorrelvine"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Cissus trifoliata"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the substrate or soil remains consistently damp but not waterlogged. It's important to simulate the damp forest floor where these mushrooms naturally grow, so misting the area lightly can help maintain humidity levels. Overwatering can lead to soggy conditions, which may promote mold and bacterial growth, so monitor the moisture carefully and use a well-draining substrate to prevent standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agaricus californicus thrives in shaded environments rather than direct sunlight. These mushrooms are typically found in forested areas where they receive dappled light through tree canopies. To mimic these conditions, grow them in an area with indirect light or partial shade. Avoid exposing the mushroom's growing area to strong, direct sunlight as it can dry out the substrate and harm the mycelium. Maintaining a stable, dark, and humid environment is key to successful cultivation."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Mushrooms like Agaricus californicus don't require traditional pruning like green plants do. Instead, it's crucial to harvest the mushrooms at the right time, which is when the cap has opened slightly but before it flattens completely. Gently twist and pull the mushrooms from their base to harvest them without disturbing the surrounding substrate too much. Regularly removing any dead or decaying material from the growing area will help prevent pests and diseases, ensuring a healthy fungal growth environment."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California Agaricus","description":"Agaricus californicus, commonly known as the California Agaricus, is a poisonous mushroom in the section Xanthodermati of the genus Agaricus.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California"],"other_name":["California Agaricus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Agaricus californicus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's best to prune in early spring before new growth resumes. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain plant health. Remember to use sterilized pruning tools to prevent the spread of disease, making clean cuts just above a node or leaf set."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"mariola","description":"Parthenium incanum, with the common names mariola and New Mexico rubber plant, is a plant in the genus Parthenium of the family Asteraceae....","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["mariola"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Parthenium incanum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Prune the plant in the spring or summer when it's actively growing. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut just above a leaf node or branch junction. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14976,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Smilax auriculata, commonly known as earleaf greenbrier, is a hardy plant that thrives in various conditions. It prefers slightly moist soil but is very drought-tolerant once established. During its establishment phase, water it regularly to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. After it is well-established, you can reduce the watering frequency, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Be mindful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot, especially if the plant is grown in poorly-draining soil. Adjust watering based on rainfall and changes in temperature to avoid foliage issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Smilax auriculata thrives in a variety of lighting conditions, from full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and more robust foliage, a location with full sun for at least 6 to 8 hours a day is ideal. However, it can also perform well in partial shade, especially in hotter climates, where the afternoon shade can protect it from intense sunlight. When grown in full shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer leaves. Ensuring that Smilax auriculata receives adequate sunlight is crucial for its health and vitality, as well as for the development of its characteristic thick, leathery leaves."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Smilax auriculata helps to manage its often vigorous growth and keeps it from becoming too invasive. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems to encourage healthy new growth. Thin out older stems to improve air circulation, and trim back any overly long or unruly vines to maintain the desired shape. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to reduce the risk of disease transmission. Regular pruning improves the plant's overall appearance and promotes healthier, more vigorous growth throughout the growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Earleaf Greenbrier","description":"Smilax auriculata, is a North American plant species native to the Bahamas, the Turks & Caicos Islands, and the southeastern United States. Common names include earleaf greenbrier and wild-bamboo, despite the fact that it is not closely related to bamboo. It is reported from Florida, Georgia, North and South Carolina, Alabama, Mississippi, and Louisiana. It grows on coastal sand dunes and in sun-lit locations in sandy woodlands at elevations of less than 100 m (333 feet).","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Earleaf Greenbrier"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Smilax auriculata"],"soil":["Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If cultivating this mushroom, maintain the moisture in its substrate by misting lightly, ensuring it remains damp but not drenched. Overwatering can lead to rot or inhibit proper growth, so aim for consistency and monitor the humidity levels closely. If grown outdoors, natural rainfall could be adequate, but during dry periods, supplemental misting may be necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agaricus hondensis, like most mushrooms, does not require sunlight to grow as they are not photosynthetic. Instead, they prefer indirect light or shaded environments since strong direct sunlight can dry out the growth medium and substrate, inhibiting proper development. If growing indoors, providing a stable environment with occasional ambient light will suffice. Outdoors, it favors shaded areas that mimic its natural understory habitat. Maintaining the right light balance helps create the optimal conditions for consistent growth and development of fruiting bodies."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically a concern for Agaricus hondensis or most other types of mushrooms since they don't grow in the same manner as traditional plants. Instead, focus on removing any mushrooms that appear to be diseased or rotting to prevent the spread of pathogens within the growth area. Additionally, harvest the mushrooms by twisting and pulling them from the substrate as they mature. This practice encourages the growth of new mushrooms, allowing the mycelium to redirect resources efficiently. Regularly cleaning the growth area helps maintain a healthy environment."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Felt-ringed Agaricus","description":"Agaricus hondensis, commonly known as the felt-ringed agaricus, is a species of fungus in the family Agaricaceae. The species was officially described in 1912 by mycologist William Alphonso Murrill, along with three other Agaricus species that have since been placed in synonymy with A. hondensis. Found in the Pacific Northwest region of North America, A. hondensis fruits in the fall under conifers or in mixed forests.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Felt-ringed Agaricus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Agaricus hondensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Evening"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15272,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Erechtites hieraciifolius, commonly known as American burnweed or fireweed, is adaptable to varying water conditions. Watering should be regular enough to keep the soil slightly damp, but care should be taken to avoid waterlogging, which could affect the plant's health. If planted outdoors, natural rainfall usually suffices, but check soil moisture occasionally, especially during dry periods. For container plants, water once the top inch of soil feels dry. Mulching can help retain soil moisture in garden settings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erechtites hieraciifolius thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily for healthy growth and optimal flowering. In hotter regions, some afternoon shade can prevent the plant from overheating. When grown in shaded areas, the plant may become leggy, trying to reach for more sunlight, which could affect its overall structure. If growing indoors, place it near a window receiving bright, indirect sunlight. Adjust its location if it shows signs of inadequate light, such as poor growth or pale leaves."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Erechtites hieraciifolius is typically minimal as it is an annual or biennial plant, completing its life cycle quickly. However, if you wish to manage its growth or limit seed spread, you can cut back the flower heads before they set seed. This not only reduces unwanted spread but can also encourage more bushy growth. Trim any dead or damaged stems to maintain the plant's overall health. Always use sharp, clean tools to prevent spreading disease. There is no strict pruning season, but regular checks for unhealthy growth can be beneficial."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"American burnweed","description":"Erechtites hieraciifolius (fireweed, American burnweed, or pilewort) is a plant in the daisy family, Asteraceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14676,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Potentilla argentea, commonly known as silver cinquefoil, prefers well-drained soil and can tolerate dry conditions once established. Once the plant is mature, it should only need watering during prolonged dry periods in the summer, as it is drought-tolerant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Potentilla argentea thrives best in full sun, where it receives at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. This helps maintain its compact growth and promotes healthy flowering. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15174,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lespedeza bicolor, or bush clover, prefers consistently moist soil but can tolerate some drought once established. Water the plant regularly during its first growing season to establish a deep root system. In subsequent years, provide water during prolonged dry periods; however, be careful not to overwater, as this plant does not like waterlogged conditions. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering. It's important to ensure good drainage to prevent root rot, especially in winter when excess moisture can be more problematic."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lespedeza bicolor thrives in full sun to partial shade. It blooms best when exposed to at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can grow in partial shade, too much shade may result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. If grown in a shaded area, make sure it receives at least a few hours of direct sun to perform well. In very hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. Always ensure that the location does not shade out during the peak flowering period in late summer."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lespedeza bicolor typically involves cutting back the previous year's growth in early spring, just before new growth begins. This plant blooms on new wood, so annual pruning encourages a bushier plant and enhances flowering. Cut back the stems to about 6 to 12 inches above the ground to maintain shape and promote lush flowering. Removing any dead, damaged, or crossing branches can also improve air circulation. Avoid pruning in summer, as this can reduce the number of flowers produced."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"shrub lespedeza","description":"Lespedeza bicolor is a species of flowering plant in the legume family known by the common names shrubby bushclover, shrub lespedeza, and bicolor lespedeza. It is native to Asia and it is widely grown as an ornamental plant. In some regions, such as the southeastern United States, it grows in the wild as an introduced and invasive species.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia"],"other_name":["shrub lespedeza"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Lespedeza bicolor"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14476,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ipomoea coccinea, commonly known as red morning glory, thrives in well-drained soil and requires regular watering to maintain its vibrant growth, especially during dry spells. Water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry. It's essential to balance this watering schedule because while the plant enjoys moisture, it does not tolerate waterlogged conditions, which can lead to root rot and other water-related issues. Ensure adequate drainage and reduce watering frequency during the winter months when the plant's growth typically slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ipomoea coccinea thrives in full sun conditions and should be positioned where it can receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. Adequate sunlight ensures that the plant blooms profusely and maintains its vibrant, healthy foliage. Though it can tolerate partial shade, the flowering may be reduced if the sunlight requirements are not met. If growing indoors or in less sunny locations, consider supplementing with grow lights to mimic the necessary light conditions for optimal growth and flower production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ipomoea coccinea should be done to control its vigorous growth and encourage a bushier, more compact shape. Regular pruning can be performed throughout the growing season by pinching back the tips of the vines to promote lateral branching. In late winter or early spring, before new growth begins, more severe pruning can be done to remove any dead or damaged stems, thereby rejuvenating the plant. Pruning also helps manage its spreading habit, keeping it from becoming too invasive in garden spaces."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"red morning glory","description":"Ipomoea coccinea is a flowering plant in the family Convolvulaceae known by several common names including red morning glory, redstar and (ambiguously) Mexican morning glory.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":["red morning glory"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Ipomoea coccinea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15566,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Juniperus flaccida, or weeping juniper, prefers well-draining soil and requires careful watering to prevent root rot. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, water the plant every 7-10 days, depending on the rainfall and temperature in your area. In fall and winter, reduce watering frequency to once every two to three weeks if the weather is cooler. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to waterlogged soil, which is detrimental to the plant’s health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Juniperus flaccida thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. It can tolerate light shade, but for optimal growth and full foliage, full sun exposure is best. If planted in an area that receives less light, the plant may become leggy and its foliage less dense. Ensure it is planted in a location that receives maximum sunlight, such as a south-facing area, to encourage the healthy development of its iconic, pendant branches and to maintain its overall vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Juniperus flaccida should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. The focus should be on removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain plant health. Additionally, prune to shape the plant if desired, but take care not to remove more than one-third of the plant’s total mass in a single season. Avoid cutting into the old wood where no green growth is visible, as junipers do not regenerate well from old wood. Light, consistent shaping can encourage bushier future growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Weeping Juniper","description":"Juniperus flaccida (drooping juniper, weeping juniper or Mexican juniper; Native American names include tláscal) is a large shrub or small tree reaching 5–10 m (rarely to 15 m) tall. It is native to central and northern Mexico (from Oaxaca northward) and the extreme southwest of Texas, United States (Brewster County). It grows at moderate altitudes of 800-2,600 m, on dry soils.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["Weeping Juniper"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Juniperus flaccida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15671,"attracts":["Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Drosera aberrans requires a medium that is consistently moist but not waterlogged. It's important to use distilled or rainwater to avoid mineral buildup, as tap water can harm the plant. During the growing season, keep the soil damp by watering from the bottom or using a tray method. Allow the surface to dry slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. In its dormancy period, reduce watering slightly but do not allow the substrate to dry out completely. Maintaining humidity can also be beneficial, so consider a humidifier or pebble tray if indoors."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Drosera aberrans thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate some direct morning sunlight, but harsh afternoon sun should be avoided as it can scorch the leaves. Aim to provide at least 6 to 8 hours of bright light daily. If growing indoors, a south or east-facing window is ideal, or supplement natural light with fluorescent or LED grow lights if necessary. Proper lighting helps maintain its vibrant color and keeps its sticky tentacles functioning properly for trapping insects. Adjust the light exposure carefully to avoid burning."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Drosera aberrans primarily involves removing dead or dying leaves to prevent mold or fungal issues. Trim these unhealthy leaves with sterilized scissors, cutting close to the base while being careful not to damage the healthy parts of the plant. Regularly remove the debris collected on the sticky traps to maintain plant health. Pruning can be done at any time of the year, but it's important to be gentle as the plant is delicate. Avoid pruning during its dormancy period, except to remove obviously dead material."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Scented Sundew","description":"Drosera aberrans is a perennial tuberous species in the genus Drosera that is native to New South Wales, South Australia, and Victoria. It grows in a rosette 3 to 5 cm in diameter with green, orange-yellow, or red leaves. It is native to southern inland South Australia, southern and central Victoria, and one single collection from New South Wales. It grows in a variety of soils from sand to laterite gravel and limestone clay in mallee woodland,...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Scented Sundew"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Drosera aberrans"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16055,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Asclepias obovata, or the pinewoods milkweed, is a drought-tolerant plant that prefers dry to moderately moist conditions. If planted in a container, use a pot with drainage holes and water only when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Antennaria neglecta thrives in full sun, which helps maintain its compact growth and brings out the best in its silvery leaves and white flowers. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15672,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Laccaria ochropurpurea, commonly known as the purple-gilled Laccaria, is a type of mushroom and does not require the traditional plant care such as watering that is needed by vascular plants. Monitoring environmental conditions and maintaining a balance is key to the successful cultivation of this mushroom species."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Laccaria ochropurpurea grows naturally on forest floors, indicating it prefers a low to moderate light environment, such as dappled sunlight under tree canopies. For cultivation, aim to replicate these conditions by providing indirect or filtered light. Direct sunlight can dry out the substrate and should be avoided since this species thrives in the moisture-rich, shaded areas typical of its native habitat. Maintaining a temperature and humidity level similar to its natural environment is crucial for its growth and fruiting. Mimicking natural light cycles can also aid in producing robust mushrooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Laccaria ochropurpurea as it is a mushroom, not a traditional plant with stems or leaves that require trimming. Removing any dead or decaying organic material nearby can prevent mold or other issues. If mushrooms need to be harvested, do so by carefully twisting and pulling them from their base to avoid disturbing the mycelium network in the substrate."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Purple-and-White Deceiver","description":"Laccaria ochropurpurea is a mushroom found under hardwood and conifers east of the Rocky Mountains.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Purple-and-White Deceiver"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Laccaria ochropurpurea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Humus-rich","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14182,"attracts":["Lichens"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Parmotrema reticulatum, like most lichens, relies on moisture from the environment rather than conventional watering. It thrives in humid conditions where it absorbs water through its surface. In cultivation, ensure that it is exposed to high humidity or misting if kept indoors. Avoid direct watering as lichens are adapted to absorb moisture from the air. Ensure adequate airflow to prevent moisture from accumulating excessively, which could lead to rot. Monitor the environment and adjust humidity levels accordingly to keep the lichen healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Parmotrema reticulatum is naturally found in environments with filtered sunlight and shade. When caring for this lichen, aim for indirect light or partial shade conditions, as direct sunlight can be too harsh, potentially causing desiccation. If indoors, place it near a north or east-facing window where it can receive subdued light. In outdoor settings, ensure it is situated in an area with dappled sunlight, like under a tree canopy. Providing the right light conditions is crucial for maintaining its color and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Parmotrema reticulatum is generally unnecessary unless you notice dead or damaged sections. If pruning is needed, gently remove these parts by hand to avoid damaging the rest of the lichen structure. As lichens grow slowly, you should exercise caution to prevent unnecessary loss of healthy tissue. Regular monitoring for any changes in color or texture can help determine if a section is dead or dying and needs removing. Pruning should be minimal and done only to maintain overall health and encourage productive growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Black Sheet Lichen","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Worldwide"],"other_name":["Black Sheet Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Parmotrema reticulatum"],"soil":["Acidic","Neutral","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14579,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Setaria leucopila, commonly known as Plains Bristlegrass, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires moderate watering. It's important to allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During its active growing season, water the plant deeply about once every two weeks. In hotter climates or during dry spells, you may need to water slightly more frequently. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant is not actively growing. Ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to avoid waterlogged conditions, which this grass variety does not tolerate well."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Setaria leucopila thrives in full sunlight and requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. This plant is well-suited for regions with high sun exposure, as it is naturally adapted to sunny, arid conditions. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may result in reduced flowering and less vigorous growth. When cultivated in pots or containers, ensure they are placed in spots with optimal sun exposure. For best results, aim to plant in open areas where sunlight is abundant throughout the day, facilitating healthy growth and development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Setaria leucopila is typically minimal, as this plant has a natural, tidy growth form. However, removing dead or damaged leaves and spent flower stalks can help maintain its appearance and encourage new growth. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Cut back the plant to about 6 inches above the ground to rejuvenate it for healthy growth in the coming season. Regularly clearing debris also helps prevent pest issues and disease. Ensure to use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent damage to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"plains bristlegrass","description":"Setaria leucopila, commonly known as streambed bristlegrass or plains bristlegrass, is a perennial prairie grass that is native to the southern plains of the United States. It reaches a height of 4 to 39 in (10 to 99 cm). Although good forage for livestock, it is only fair for wildlife use. It reproduces by seeds and tillers.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["plains bristlegrass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Setaria leucopila"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14477,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Acer griseum, commonly known as the Paperbark Maple, prefers consistently moist, well-drained soil, making it important to water regularly, especially during dry spells. Young trees require more frequent watering to establish their root systems, so weekly watering is ideal during the first few years. For more mature trees, ensure that the soil is allowed to partially dry out between waterings to avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot. Additionally, using mulch can help retain soil moisture and protect the roots, but avoid covering the trunk directly with mulch to prevent any rotting issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acer griseum thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least four to six hours of direct sunlight each day to maintain its vibrant foliage color, especially in the fall, when it turns bright reds and oranges. However, it can tolerate partial shade, which is useful in hotter climates where midday sun can cause leaf scorch. When choosing a location, ensure the tree is protected from harsh afternoon sun if partial shade is not available. Additionally, consider the site's exposure to wind, as persistent strong winds can stress the tree and affect its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Acer griseum should be done in late winter or early spring while the tree is still dormant. This timing helps prevent sap bleed from cuts. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to maintain a healthy structure. Additionally, thin out crowded areas to increase light penetration and air circulation within the canopy. Since Paperbark Maple has a naturally beautiful shape, avoid excessive pruning, which can detract from its appearance. Always use clean, sharp tools to make smooth cuts and apply pruning sealer if necessary to protect the cuts during the plant's healing process."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Paperbark Maple","description":"Acer griseum (paperbark maple; simplified Chinese: 血皮枫; traditional Chinese: 血皮楓; pinyin: xuè pí fēng) is a species of flowering plant in the family Sapindaceae, native to central China. Acer griseum is found in the Chinese provinces of Gansu, Henan, Hubei, Hunan, Shaanxi, Shanxi and Sichuan, at altitudes of 1,500–2,000 m (4,921–6,562 ft).","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central China"],"other_name":["Paperbark Maple"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Acer griseum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, you should maintain a consistent watering schedule, ensuring that the soil remains damp but not overly saturated. In the dormant period, you can reduce watering slightly but do not allow the soil to completely dry out. It prefers high humidity, so misting can also help meet its moisture needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Psychotria poeppigiana prefers partial to full shade, mimicking its natural understory habitat in tropical forests. It thrives where it receives filtered light or dappled sunlight throughout the day. Direct exposure to harsh sunlight can cause leaf burn and damage to the plant, so it should be protected from intense afternoon sun. In indoor settings, it should be placed in a spot that receives bright, indirect light for optimal growth. If it's not getting enough light, the plant might become leggy, indicating the need for a brighter location."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not a major requirement for Psychotria poeppigiana, but it can benefit from occasional trimming to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is during the growing season, in the spring or early summer. You should remove any dead or damaged branches to keep the plant healthy. Additionally, light pruning of the tips can encourage more lateral growth and create a fuller appearance. Use clean and sharp pruning tools to make clean cuts, which minimize the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"hot lips","description":"...","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"White\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":["hot lips"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Psychotria poeppigiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15869,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tithonia tubaeformis, commonly known as Mexican sunflower, prefers well-drained soil and does best when allowed to dry out slightly between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot. Water the plant deeply once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During the growing season, it may require more frequent watering, especially in very hot or dry conditions. In contrast, reduce watering during the winter months when the plant is not actively growing. Ensure that the pot or garden area has adequate drainage to prevent water from pooling around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tithonia tubaeformis thrives in full sunlight and requires at least six to eight hours of direct sun each day to perform well. It is a sun-loving plant and will produce more vibrant flowers when positioned in a bright location. If grown in partial shade, it may lead to weaker stems and fewer blooms. Consider planting in a south-facing garden bed or area that receives unobstructed light throughout the day. When growing indoors or in less sunny environments, supplement lighting may be needed to mimic full sun conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tithonia tubaeformis encourages bushier growth and more abundant blooms. In early spring, prune back any dead or damaged branches to promote new growth. Throughout the growing season, regularly deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooming. If the plant becomes leggy, consider cutting it back by up to one-third to rejuvenate it. Pruning should be done with clean, sharp shears to prevent disease. At the end of the growing season, cut back the plants to prepare them for the dormant period if they are perennial in your climate zone."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tree marigold","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["tree marigold"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Tithonia tubaeformis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14377,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Viscum capense, also known as Cape Mistletoe, typically absorbs nutrients and water from its host plant, but if cultivated independently, it requires minimal watering. It thrives in well-drained soil that can retain some moisture. During its active growth period, maintain a consistent moisture level without allowing the soil to become waterlogged. Over-watering should be avoided to prevent root rot. During dormant periods, reduce watering significantly, keeping the soil only slightly moist. Ensuring proper drainage will help maintain the right water balance for this semi-parasitic plant species."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viscum capense generally prefers partial shade to dappled sunlight, as it naturally grows attached to host trees where full sunlight is filtered through the canopy. When grown without a host, providing a location with bright, indirect light will mimic its natural environment. Avoid placing it in direct harsh sunlight, which can scorch its foliage, or overly shaded areas that can hinder its growth. A spot with morning sun and afternoon shade often works well. Adjust the light exposure based on the plant's response to ensure it remains healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Viscum capense should focus on maintaining its shape and promoting healthy growth. If growing on a host tree, monitor its growth to ensure it doesn't overtake the host. Remove any dead or diseased branches regularly, and trim back excessively long shoots to maintain a manageable size. Pruning is typically done during the dormant season to minimize stress on the plant. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to prevent damage and the spread of any potential infections. Regular pruning helps improve air circulation and light penetration, contributing to the plant's overall health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cape Mistletoe","description":"Viscum capense (common name, Cape mistletoe) is a species of Mistletoe that is indigenous to South Africa, especially the area from Cape Town, northwards along the coast up to Namibia, and eastwards as far as the Eastern Cape province.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"White\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Cape Mistletoe"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Viscum capense"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
