{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14875,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Antennaria neglecta, commonly known as the field pussytoes, prefers well-drained soil and is highly drought-tolerant. It requires minimal watering once established, making it ideal for xeriscaping and rock gardens. During its first year, water the plant moderately, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Once established, water it sparingly, only during prolonged droughts. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil is not consistently waterlogged. If planted in a container, use a pot with drainage holes and water only when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Antennaria neglecta thrives in full sun, which helps maintain its compact growth and brings out the best in its silvery leaves and white flowers. Plant it in a location that receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In climates with intense sun and heat, it may tolerate partial shade, particularly in the hotter parts of the day, but flowering may be less prolific. Planting in too much shade can result in leggy growth and reduced flower production. Full sun exposure generally results in a healthier plant with more vibrant blooms and foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Antennaria neglecta is generally minimal. Remove spent blooms after flowering to maintain the plant’s appearance and potentially encourage a second bloom in the season. During late fall or early spring, cut back any winter-damaged foliage to promote a tidy appearance and vigorous new growth. Avoid heavy pruning, as the plant’s natural form is low-maintenance and pleasing. Any dead or diseased material should be removed promptly to prevent spread. Always use clean, sharp tools to make cuts, ensuring clean wounds that promote quick healing. Overall, little pruning is needed to keep this plant healthy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Field Pussytoes","description":"Antennaria neglecta is a North American species of flowering plants in the daisy family known by the common name field pussytoes. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15468,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Prunus angustifolia, commonly known as Chickasaw plum, prefers moderate watering. It is drought-tolerant but thrives with consistent watering during dry periods, especially in its early growth stages. Water the plant thoroughly but allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. When established, it requires less frequent watering. An ideal practice is to water deeply once every week or two during the growing season, reducing the frequency as the plant becomes more mature. Overwatering should be avoided to maintain the health and vigor of the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prunus angustifolia thrives in full sunlight, which is essential for its optimal growth and fruit production. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight a day to bloom and produce fruit effectively. Although it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure ensures vibrant blooms and healthy fruit development. In shaded areas, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers and fruits. Plant it in a location where it won't be overshadowed by larger trees or structures to maximize its sunlight exposure, promoting a healthier, more productive plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Prunus angustifolia helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to prevent disease spread. Thin out crossing branches to improve air circulation and light penetration within the canopy. You can also lightly shape the tree to keep it looking neat. Avoid heavy pruning since this species blooms on old wood; excessive cutting may reduce flowering. Regular, minimal pruning will help the plant develop a strong structure and enhance its aesthetic appeal."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Chickasaw plum","description":"Prunus angustifolia pronounced (PROO-nus an-gus-tih-FOLE-ee-uh), known commonly as Chickasaw plum, Cherokee plum, Florida sand plum, sandhill plum, or sand plum, is a North American species of plum-bearing tree. It was originally cultivated by Native Americans before the arrival of Europeans While Prunus is the classical name for European plums, angustifolia refers to its narrow leaves.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Chickasaw plum"],"pest_susceptibility":["Canker","Caterpillars","Leaf Spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Prunus angustifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15672,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Laccaria ochropurpurea, commonly known as the purple-gilled Laccaria, is a type of mushroom and does not require the traditional plant care such as watering that is needed by vascular plants. However, it thrives in moist environments where there is sufficient natural rainfall or ambient humidity. In a cultivated setting, ensure the substrate remains consistently moist, mimicking its natural woodland habitat. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent substrate waterlogging, which can be detrimental to its growth. Monitoring environmental conditions and maintaining a balance is key to the successful cultivation of this mushroom species."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Laccaria ochropurpurea grows naturally on forest floors, indicating it prefers a low to moderate light environment, such as dappled sunlight under tree canopies. For cultivation, aim to replicate these conditions by providing indirect or filtered light. Direct sunlight can dry out the substrate and should be avoided since this species thrives in the moisture-rich, shaded areas typical of its native habitat. Maintaining a temperature and humidity level similar to its natural environment is crucial for its growth and fruiting. Mimicking natural light cycles can also aid in producing robust mushrooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Laccaria ochropurpurea as it is a mushroom, not a traditional plant with stems or leaves that require trimming. Instead, focus on providing optimal growth conditions such as appropriate substrate composition and moisture levels. Removing any dead or decaying organic material nearby can prevent mold or other issues. If mushrooms need to be harvested, do so by carefully twisting and pulling them from their base to avoid disturbing the mycelium network in the substrate."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Purple-and-White Deceiver","description":"Laccaria ochropurpurea is a mushroom found under hardwood and conifers east of the Rocky Mountains.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Purple-and-White Deceiver"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Laccaria ochropurpurea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Humus-rich","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14579,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Setaria leucopila, commonly known as Plains Bristlegrass, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires moderate watering. It's important to allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During its active growing season, water the plant deeply about once every two weeks. In hotter climates or during dry spells, you may need to water slightly more frequently. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant is not actively growing. Ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to avoid waterlogged conditions, which this grass variety does not tolerate well."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Setaria leucopila thrives in full sunlight and requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. This plant is well-suited for regions with high sun exposure, as it is naturally adapted to sunny, arid conditions. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may result in reduced flowering and less vigorous growth. When cultivated in pots or containers, ensure they are placed in spots with optimal sun exposure. For best results, aim to plant in open areas where sunlight is abundant throughout the day, facilitating healthy growth and development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Setaria leucopila is typically minimal, as this plant has a natural, tidy growth form. However, removing dead or damaged leaves and spent flower stalks can help maintain its appearance and encourage new growth. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Cut back the plant to about 6 inches above the ground to rejuvenate it for healthy growth in the coming season. Regularly clearing debris also helps prevent pest issues and disease. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14477,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Acer griseum, commonly known as the Paperbark Maple, prefers consistently moist, well-drained soil, making it important to water regularly, especially during dry spells. Young trees require more frequent watering to establish their root systems, so weekly watering is ideal during the first few years. For more mature trees, ensure that the soil is allowed to partially dry out between waterings to avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot. Additionally, using mulch can help retain soil moisture and protect the roots, but avoid covering the trunk directly with mulch to prevent any rotting issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acer griseum thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least four to six hours of direct sunlight each day to maintain its vibrant foliage color, especially in the fall, when it turns bright reds and oranges. However, it can tolerate partial shade, which is useful in hotter climates where midday sun can cause leaf scorch. When choosing a location, ensure the tree is protected from harsh afternoon sun if partial shade is not available. Additionally, consider the site's exposure to wind, as persistent strong winds can stress the tree and affect its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Acer griseum should be done in late winter or early spring while the tree is still dormant. This timing helps prevent sap bleed from cuts. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to maintain a healthy structure. Additionally, thin out crowded areas to increase light penetration and air circulation within the canopy. Since Paperbark Maple has a naturally beautiful shape, avoid excessive pruning, which can detract from its appearance. Always use clean, sharp tools to make smooth cuts and apply pruning sealer if necessary to protect the cuts during the plant's healing process."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Paperbark Maple","description":"Acer griseum (paperbark maple; simplified Chinese: 血皮枫; traditional Chinese: 血皮楓; pinyin: xuè pí fēng) is a species of flowering plant in the family Sapindaceae, native to central China. Acer griseum is found in the Chinese provinces of Gansu, Henan, Hubei, Hunan, Shaanxi, Shanxi and Sichuan, at altitudes of 1,500–2,000 m (4,921–6,562 ft).","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central China"],"other_name":["Paperbark Maple"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Acer griseum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Consider planting in a south-facing garden bed or area that receives unobstructed light throughout the day. When growing indoors or in less sunny environments, supplement lighting may be needed to mimic full sun conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tithonia tubaeformis encourages bushier growth and more abundant blooms. In early spring, prune back any dead or damaged branches to promote new growth. Throughout the growing season, regularly deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooming. If the plant becomes leggy, consider cutting it back by up to one-third to rejuvenate it. Pruning should be done with clean, sharp shears to prevent disease. At the end of the growing season, cut back the plants to prepare them for the dormant period if they are perennial in your climate zone."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tree marigold","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["tree marigold"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Tithonia tubaeformis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When grown without a host, providing a location with bright, indirect light will mimic its natural environment. Avoid placing it in direct harsh sunlight, which can scorch its foliage, or overly shaded areas that can hinder its growth. A spot with morning sun and afternoon shade often works well. Adjust the light exposure based on the plant's response to ensure it remains healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Viscum capense should focus on maintaining its shape and promoting healthy growth. If growing on a host tree, monitor its growth to ensure it doesn't overtake the host. Remove any dead or diseased branches regularly, and trim back excessively long shoots to maintain a manageable size. Pruning is typically done during the dormant season to minimize stress on the plant. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to prevent damage and the spread of any potential infections. Regular pruning helps improve air circulation and light penetration, contributing to the plant's overall health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cape Mistletoe","description":"Viscum capense (common name, Cape mistletoe) is a species of Mistletoe that is indigenous to South Africa, especially the area from Cape Town, northwards along the coast up to Namibia, and eastwards as far as the Eastern Cape province.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"White\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Cape Mistletoe"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Viscum capense"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15175,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Angelica atropurpurea, commonly known as American Angelica, prefers a consistently moist environment as it is native to areas near water bodies like streams and wetlands. Ensure the soil remains damp but well-drained, avoiding waterlogged conditions. During the growing season, water regularly to keep the soil from drying out completely. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and regulate soil temperature, providing an optimal environment for root development."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives in partial to full sunlight, adapting best in environments where it receives 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day, preferably in the morning. While it can tolerate some shade, especially during the hottest part of the day, too much shade might affect its flowering and overall vigor. When planting in a garden, consider locations that receive morning sun and are slightly shaded in the afternoon to mimic its natural habitat. In excessively hot or dry climates, additional shading might be necessary to prevent the plant from wilting or becoming stressed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Angelica atropurpurea is usually minimal, primarily focusing on removing dead or damaged foliage to maintain plant health and aesthetics. After the flowering period, you can cut back the stems to encourage new growth and prevent self-seeding if desired, as this plant is a biennial and tends to self-sow effectively. Carefully remove any browning or decayed leaves to prevent disease spread. If the plant becomes too large or leggy, you can selectively trim back to improve its shape and appearance. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent the introduction of pathogens."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"purple-stemmed angelica","description":"Angelica atropurpurea, known commonly as purplestem angelica, great angelica, American angelica, high angelica, and masterwort, is a species of flowering plant that can be found in moist and swampy woodlands, mostly by riverbanks, in eastern North America. It has been found in eastern Canada (Nunavut, Ontario, Quebec, Labrador, Newfoundland, all 3 Maritime Provinces) and the United States (from New England south as far as North Carolina, and west to Minnesota, Iowa, and Tennessee).","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["purple-stemmed angelica"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Angelica atropurpurea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Afterward, it only needs supplemental watering during prolonged dry spells. Avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot, especially in clay soils. This trimming helps to tidy up the appearance of the plant and encourages robust, new shoots. Avoid cutting the plant too early as the foliage can provide winter interest and protection for the crown from cold weather. Pruning is not essential annually but can be done as needed to remove dead material."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Needle-and-thread Grass","description":"Hesperostipa comata, commonly known as needle-and-thread grass, is a species of grass native to North America, especially the western third. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14876,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Nandina domestica, commonly known as heavenly bamboo, prefers well-drained soil and moderate watering. Water the plant regularly during its first growing season to establish a deep, extensive root system. Once established, reduce the frequency of watering. It is drought-tolerant, but during extended dry periods, you should water it deeply, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. In the winter months, reduce watering even further as the plant's growth slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nandina domestica thrives in a range of sunlight conditions from full sun to partial shade. However, for the best foliage color, full sun is preferable, as the sunlight enhances the color of the leaves and berries. In hot climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent the foliage from scorching. Plants in shadier locations may not have as vibrant foliage and could grow more leggy. If planted indoors, make sure it is near a bright window, ensuring it receives several hours of indirect sunlight each day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Nandina domestica can help maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. The best time for pruning is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches first. The soil should be kept evenly moist without becoming waterlogged, which can lead to root rot. During the plant's active growing season, increase the frequency of watering to ensure the roots remain moist. However, in cooler months or when the plant is dormant, reduce watering to prevent over-saturation, allowing the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex radiata prefers partial to full shade but can tolerate some sunlight if the soil is kept moist. Ideally, it should be positioned in a location that receives filtered or dappled sunlight, such as under a canopy of trees. Direct, harsh sunlight can scorch the leaves and dry out the soil quickly, stressing the plant. In hotter climates, ensure the plant is shaded during the hottest part of the day to prevent heat damage. When planted in shade, this sedge will thrive with its lush green foliage and can be a vibrant addition to shaded garden areas."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex radiata involves removing dead or damaged foliage to promote healthy growth and improve the plant's appearance. Prune in early spring before new growth appears, using clean, sharp scissors or garden shears. Trim back any browned or old leaves at the base, being careful not to cut new shoots. Regular pruning helps to maintain a tidy appearance and supports the plant's growth by allowing light and air to reach the base. If the plant becomes too large or unruly, it can be divided in the spring to control its size and rejuvenate the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"bracted sedge","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["bracted sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Carex radiata"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14580,"attracts":["birds","butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sorghastrum nutans, commonly known as Indiangrass, is a drought-tolerant native grass that requires minimal watering once established. Initially, while the plant is establishing itself, regular watering is necessary to keep the soil consistently moist. Once the grass is established, it only needs supplemental watering during extended periods of drought or dry spells. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot and other issues. The soil should be allowed to dry out between waterings to prevent excessive moisture buildup and ensure healthy root development."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sorghastrum nutans thrives in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. It can tolerate light shade, but reduced sunlight can lead to a less vigorous growth and diminished flowering. This grass is well adapted to a variety of conditions, but optimal sun exposure ensures its best coloration and plume development. When planting Indiangrass, make sure it's placed in a location where it won't be overshadowed by taller plants or structures, which could limit its access to adequate sunlight and affect its overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sorghastrum nutans is not typically necessary for its health, but it can benefit from being cut back annually to manage its size and promote healthy growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Cut back old foliage to about 4-6 inches above the ground. This helps rejuvenate the plant and encourages new shoots to emerge, keeping the grass looking neat and vigorous. Avoid pruning too frequently or during the growing season as this can disrupt the plant's natural development cycle."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Indiangrass","description":"Sorghastrum nutans, commonly known as either Indiangrass or yellow Indiangrass, is a North American prairie grass found in the central and eastern United States and Canada, especially in the Great Plains and tallgrass prairies.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Indiangrass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Sorghastrum nutans"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is recommended to avoid heavy pruning, as sourwood trees naturally develop an attractive shape. Lightly trim to maintain structure and health. Regular pruning can also help in controlling its size, especially if the tree is planted in a space-constrained area."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"sourwood","description":"Sourwood or sorrel tree, Oxydendrum arboreum, /ˌɒksɪˈdɛndrəm ɑːrˈbɔːriəm/ is the sole species in the genus Oxydendrum, in the family Ericaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15568,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dioon edule, or the Mexican cycad, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires well-draining soil to prevent root rot. Water this plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the topsoil to dry out completely between watering sessions. Overwatering can be detrimental, so ensure that the soil does not remain waterlogged for extended periods. During the growing season, spring and summer, you may need to water more frequently, approximately once every two to three weeks. In contrast, reduce watering during the fall and winter when the plant's growth slows, watering only once a month or when the soil is dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dioon edule thrives in bright, indirect light and can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in the early morning or late afternoon. However, avoid exposing it to harsh midday sun, which can scorch the leaves. In its natural habitat, it experiences partial shade from taller plants, so replicating these conditions indoors or in a garden setting is ideal. If kept indoors, place it near a bright window with filtered light. If you notice the plant becoming leggy or the leaves yellowing, it may be an indication that it is not receiving adequate light, and you should adjust its position accordingly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Dioon edule is generally minimal and usually involves the removal of old or damaged leaves to maintain the plant's appearance and health. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to cut the leaves as close to the trunk as possible without damaging it. Regularly inspect the plant for any signs of pest infestations or diseases and remove affected leaves promptly. Since this plant grows slowly, avoid over-pruning, as it can hinder growth and reduce vigor. Focus on maintaining a neat and tidy appearance rather than altering its natural growth pattern."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chestnut Dioon","description":"Dioon edule, the chestnut dioon, is a cycad native to Mexico, also known as palma de la virgen. Cycads are among the oldest seed plants and even pre-date the dinosaurs. It belongs to the Zamiaceae plant family within the order Cycadales. The genus name \"Dioon\" means \"two-egged\", referring to the two ovules (see photo below).","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Chestnut Dioon"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Dioon edule"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15870,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Buddleja cordata prefers well-drained soil and should not be overwatered, as this can lead to root rot. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During the growing season in spring and summer, you may need to water more frequently if the weather is particularly hot and dry. Reduce watering in the fall and winter when the plant is not actively growing. Always adjust watering based on local climate conditions and rainfall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Buddleja cordata thrives in full sun and needs at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to produce its best flowering display. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may result in reduced flowering and leggy growth. If planted in a spot with less sun, the plant might stretch toward the light, and blooming can be significantly diminished. Ensure that the plant is located in a sunny spot in the garden, preferably in a location that receives consistent sunlight throughout the day for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is an essential part of caring for Buddleja cordata to encourage healthy growth and abundant flowering. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to maintain an open and airy structure. You can also prune the plant to shape it and control its size. Cutting back about a third of the previous year's growth can promote vigorous flowering. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and reduce disease risk."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tepozan","description":"Buddleja cordata is endemic to Mexico, growing along forest edges and water courses at elevations of 1500–3000 m; it has also naturalized in parts of Ethiopia. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14274,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agrocybe pediades, a type of mushroom, prefers moisture-rich environments, reflecting its natural habitat in grassy and open areas with good drainage. Avoid standing water, which can cause fungal infections or rot. It’s ideal to mist or water these mushrooms lightly to ensure the substrate stays damp. Monitor humidity levels to match their native environment which typically involves moderate to high humidity, essential for their fruiting bodies to properly develop."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"As a mushroom species, Agrocybe pediades doesn't require direct sunlight. In fact, they thrive in indirect light or diffuse sunlight similar to their natural habitats in grassy open woodlands. If you're cultivating them indoors, replicate these conditions with controlled lighting that mimics indirect sunlight, or use fluorescent lighting suited for low light requirements. Too much direct sunlight can dry out the substrate and inhibit growth, so maintaining a balance of indirect light and shade is essential to support their development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning typically isn't necessary for Agrocybe pediades as it is a type of mushroom, not a plant requiring pruning for growth management. However, if you are cultivating them in a controlled environment, you should remove any mushrooms that show signs of rot, mold, or disease to prevent these conditions from spreading. This can be done by gently pulling or cutting out the affected mushrooms from the substrate. Regularly harvesting the mature mushrooms will also help in maintaining the overall health and productivity of the crop."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Common Fieldcap","description":"Agrocybe pediades is a typically lawn and other types of grassland mushroom, but can also grow on mulch containing horse manure. During hot and dry spells, ensure the plant receives enough water to maintain its requirements, as it dislikes excessively dry conditions. Reduce watering in the fall as the plant enters its dormancy phase. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and maintain an even moisture level, but ensure good drainage to avoid root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lobelia spicata thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for robust growth and abundant flowering. If planted in partial shade, ensure it still receives some morning or afternoon sun to prevent it from becoming leggy and sparse. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense sunlight and heat stress. Adjust the light exposure based on your specific regional climate to optimize the plant's health and blooming potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lobelia spicata is generally required to help maintain its appearance and promote healthy growth. Regularly deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooming through the growing season. In late fall or early spring, cut back faded flower stalks and any dead or damaged foliage to allow for fresh growth. It's also advisable to thin the plant if it becomes overly dense, which will improve air circulation and reduce the risk of disease. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools for the best results."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pale-spiked lobelia","description":"Lobelia spicata, commonly called the pale spiked lobelia, is flowering plant in the bellflower family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["pale-spiked lobelia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Lobelia spicata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Keep its substrate, such as decaying wood or compost, damp but not waterlogged. This is key to mushroom growth, as too much water can lead to substrate saturation and hinder fruiting. Mist the substrate regularly to maintain humidity, particularly in dry conditions, but avoid creating standing water. The environment should mimic damp forest conditions, with a relative humidity of around 80-90%."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pholiota squarrosoides doesn’t require direct sunlight as it’s a fungal species that typically grows in shaded, forested areas. Instead, it thrives in areas with indirect light or complete shade. Sunlight can actually be detrimental, as it may dry out the growing substrate, which is contrary to the moist environment these fungi prefer. If grown indoors, select a location away from direct sun exposure, such as a shaded part of a garden with dappled light or in a humid room away from windows."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Being a fungus, Pholiota squarrosoides doesn’t require traditional pruning like plants do. Instead, focus on harvesting the mushrooms at the right time. Generally, harvest when the caps are fully developed but before they begin to deteriorate or turn mushy. This is usually when the cap is convex, and the gills are exposed. Use a clean, sharp knife to cut the fruiting body at the base to avoid damaging the mycelium network. Proper harvesting helps ensure the continued growth of new mushrooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sharp-scaly Pholiota","description":"Pholiota squarrosoides is a species of mushroom in the family Strophariaceae. It is similar to the species Pholiota squarrosa. This lichen obtains moisture through atmospheric humidity and rainfall. In cultivation or decorative use, ensuring high humidity may help maintain its health. Spraying with distilled water periodically can be beneficial, particularly in dry environments. It's important to avoid overwatering, which can lead to rot, and to ensure that the plant is not submerged in water. Remember, Usnea generally thrives in conditions resembling its natural habitat, where moisture and air flow are balanced."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Usnea rubicunda requires filtered or indirect sunlight, as it naturally grows in shaded or partially shaded environments. Direct sunlight should be avoided, as it can dry out the lichen and damage its structure. If growing indoors or in a decorative setting, placing it in a spot with dappled light or using sheer curtains to diffuse sunlight can mimic its natural conditions. Ensuring the lichen is not subjected to direct, harsh light will help maintain its moisture balance and vibrant coloration."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not a common practice with Usnea rubicunda as it is with flowering plants. However, if used decoratively or for study, any damaged or unsightly parts can be removed. Care should be taken not to disrupt the main body of the lichen, as it is sensitive. In areas where it is being cultivated outside its natural environment, monitoring its shape and structure to prevent tangling or overgrowth can be beneficial. Removing dead sections may help maintain a cleaner aesthetic but handle with care to avoid disruption to the lichen’s overall structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Red Beard Lichen","description":"Usnea rubicunda, commonly known as the red beard lichen, is a type of arboreal lichen native to temperate regions in North, Central and South America, as well as Europe, Eastern Asia, and North Africa. At the end of the growing season, you can cut back any dead foliage to tidy up the plant and prevent disease. Be gentle while handling, as the plant has a delicate structure. Overall, light pruning as needed keeps the plant healthy without excessive manipulation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"twinleaf","description":"Jeffersonia which is also known as twinleaf or rheumatism root, is a small genus of herbaceous perennial plants in the family Berberidaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14478,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Melaleuca quinquenervia, also known as the paperbark tree, prefers moist conditions, as it is native to swamps and wetlands. It should be kept well-watered, especially when young, to help establish a strong root system. However, once established, this plant can tolerate some periods of drought due to its adaptability. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent root rot, but the surface should remain consistently moist, particularly during hot, dry spells. Avoid waterlogging the soil, as this can adversely affect the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Melaleuca quinquenervia thrives in full sunlight, ideally receiving at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. This exposure is crucial for healthy growth and flowering. It can tolerate partial shade, but optimal growth and flowering benefit from as much sunlight as possible. If planted in a shaded area, the growth might be slower, and the structure may become spindly. Ensure the planting location allows sufficient sunlight, especially in the morning to help dry the leaves and prevent mildew or other moisture-related issues."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Melaleuca quinquenervia is primarily done to maintain its shape and remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. It is best to prune the tree in late winter to early spring before new growth begins. Light trimming can be done to encourage a more bushy growth habit, but avoid heavy pruning which may stress the plant. Suckers, or shoots emerging from the base, should be removed regularly to help direct energy into the main growth structures. Additionally, trimming improves air circulation within the canopy, reducing pest and disease risks."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Broad-leaved paperbark","description":"Melaleuca quinquenervia, commonly known as the broad-leaved paperbark, paper bark tea tree, punk tree or niaouli, is a small- to medium-sized tree of the myrtle family, Myrtaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15471,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cercidiphyllum japonicum, commonly known as the Katsura tree, requires regular watering, especially during its early years of growth or when newly planted. It prefers consistently moist soil, and it's important to ensure the soil does not dry out completely between watering sessions. During the growing season, water deeply once a week, increasing frequency during hot, dry periods. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture. However, avoid waterlogging as it can lead to root rot. In winter, reduce watering frequency, allowing natural precipitation to sustain the plant unless you experience extended dry spells."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cercidiphyllum japonicum thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least four hours of direct sunlight daily to develop its characteristic autumn foliage colors. However, in regions with intensely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. The Katsura tree will tolerate dappled sunlight, but may not achieve its full potential in shade. Planting it in a location that receives morning sun and afternoon shade is ideal in hotter climates, while full sun is preferred in cooler conditions to enhance growth and coloration."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Cercidiphyllum japonicum should be minimal, as it naturally forms an attractive structure. However, you can prune to remove any dead or damaged branches, which can be done in late winter or early spring before the tree begins to leaf out. If you wish to maintain a specific shape or control size, light pruning can be done after the flowering period. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can affect the natural shape and growth of the tree. Always use sterilized, sharp tools to make clean cuts, and avoid pruning more than one-third of the tree in any given year."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"katsura tree","description":"Cercidiphyllum japonicum, known as the katsura (from its Japanese name カツラ, 桂), is a species of flowering tree in the family Cercidiphyllaceae native to China and Japan. It is sometimes called caramel tree for the light caramel smell it emits during leaf fall.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Japan","China"],"other_name":["katsura tree"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Cercidiphyllum japonicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It’s recommended to use distilled or rainwater if possible to avoid mineral buildup."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The walking palm thrives in bright, indirect sunlight and can tolerate partial shade. Ideally, it should be placed in a location that mimics its natural understory habitat in tropical forests. Direct, harsh sunlight should be avoided, as it can scorch the leaves. Avoid excessive pruning, as it can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"walking palm","description":"Socratea exorrhiza, the Walking Palm or Cashapona, is a palm native to rainforests in tropical Central and South America. Many species of epiphyte have been found growing on the palms. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14778,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vaccinium elliottii, commonly known as Elliott's blueberry, prefers consistently moist soil but should not be waterlogged. It requires regular watering, especially during dry spells or drought conditions, to ensure the soil remains evenly moist. However, over-watering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. Installing mulch around the base can help retain soil moisture. During the growing season, deep watering once a week should suffice, ensuring the water reaches the root zone. Always adjust the watering schedule according to weather conditions and soil type."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Elliott's blueberry thrives best in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and fruit production, provide it with at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may lead to reduced flowering and fruiting. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. Ideally, plant it in an area where it receives morning sunlight while being protected during the hottest part of the afternoon. Ensuring adequate sunlight exposure is crucial for healthy fruit development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vaccinium elliottii should be carried out late in the winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on removing any dead or diseased wood and crossing branches to open up the bush's center, promoting good air circulation. This encourages healthy growth and improves fruit production. Reducing older stems can rejuvenate the shrub and enhance berry production. Minimal shaping is generally sufficient as these plants naturally maintain an attractive form. Regular maintenance pruning can ensure the bush remains productive and healthy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"mayberry","description":"Vaccinium elliottii (Elliott's blueberry) is a species of Vaccinium in the blueberry group (Vaccinium sect. Cyanococcus). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14878,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phlox pilosa, commonly known as prairie phlox, prefers moderate watering. It thrives in well-drained soil, where it can dry out slightly between waterings. During the growing season, water the plant deeply once a week, ensuring the soil is evenly moist, but not soggy. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to allow the top layer of soil to dry out before watering again. In cooler or rainier seasons, reduce the frequency of watering and rely on natural rainfall, adjusting as necessary to prevent over-saturation of the soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phlox pilosa thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sun each day to bloom optimally and maintain its vibrant coloring. Planting in a location with ample sunlight will result in healthier plants with more abundant flowers. Though it can tolerate partial shade, less sun can lead to leggy growth and reduced blooming. If planting in an area with partial shade, monitor the plant's growth closely and consider supplementary lighting if it appears to struggle or bloom sparsely. Ensure the location also offers open air circulation to prevent mildew."},{"type":"pruning","description":"To maintain a healthy Phlox pilosa plant, require minimal pruning, but occasional trimming can promote more robust growth. After the main flowering period, deadheading spent blooms can encourage the plant to produce more flowers. In late autumn or early winter, trim back the stems to just above ground level to prepare the plant for the dormant season. This pruning can help prevent disease and rejuvenate the plant for the following spring. Throughout the growing season, remove any dead or diseased foliage to maintain plant health and appearance."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"prairie phlox","description":"Phlox pilosa (downy phlox or prairie phlox) is an herbaceous plant in the family Polemoniaceae. It is native to eastern North America, where it is found in open areas such as prairies and woodlands.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["prairie phlox"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Phlox pilosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15773,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Himantoglossum hircinum, commonly known as the lizard orchid, requires moderate watering. It is important to ensure that the soil is well-drained to prevent root rot. Water the plant thoroughly during its growing season, typically spring and early summer, and reduce watering in the dormant period, which usually starts in late summer. Allow the soil surface to dry out between waterings to avoid overwatering. During the active growth period, keep the soil consistently moist but not soggy. Proper drainage conditions should be maintained as waterlogged soil can harm the plant's roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Himantoglossum hircinum thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal growth, place the plant in an area where it can receive at least 6 hours of sunlight daily, mimicking its natural habitat's exposure. This orchid can adapt to dappled light environments, especially in hotter climates where direct midday sun might be too intense. However, in cooler climates or during its growing phase, more direct sun is beneficial. Observe the plant for any signs of sunburn or stress, such as scorched leaves, and adjust its sun exposure as needed to maintain plant health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning requirements for the Himantoglossum hircinum are minimal, as this orchid is primarily noted for its natural upright growth form. However, it’s beneficial to remove any dead or damaged leaves or flower stems to preserve the plant’s vigor and appearance. Deadhead spent flower spikes after blooming to direct energy back to the bulb for next year's growth. Use sterilized pruning shears to prevent disease and make clean cuts to minimize stress on the plant. Pruning is typically performed after the flowering period, ensuring plant energy is conserved."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lizard Orchid","description":"Himantoglossum hircinum, the lizard orchid, is a species of orchid in the genus Himantoglossum found across Europe, from Spain eastwards to the Balkans and in western North Africa. It is usually rare but can sometimes be found in great numbers in suitable habitats. This orchid grows in dry meadows, rocky areas, and open woods. It may reach a height of 133 centimetres (52 in).","family":null,"flower_color":"Greenish-brown","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","North Africa"],"other_name":["Lizard Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Himantoglossum hircinum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Calcareous","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14582,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Yucca campestris, also known as the Plains Yucca, is drought-tolerant and requires infrequent watering. It's best to allow the soil to completely dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. In general, watering every two to three weeks should be sufficient, and even less frequently during the winter. Overwatering is a common mistake, as these plants are adapted to arid environments and prefer dry conditions. Always ensure good drainage in the pot or garden bed to avoid standing water, which can be detrimental."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Yucca campestris thrives in full sun and requires plenty of direct sunlight to grow healthily. It should be placed in a location where it can receive at least six to eight hours of sunlight per day. While the plant can tolerate some shade, too much shade can lead to leggy growth and fewer flowers. If grown indoors, place it near a bright south or west-facing window. Adequate sunlight is crucial for this plant's well-being, given its native habitat in sunlight-rich areas."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Yucca campestris is mainly about maintaining its shape and removing dead or damaged leaves. It's best to prune in the spring when new growth begins. Use sharp, clean shears to cut away any brown or yellowing leaves at the base. If the plant becomes too tall or overgrown, the top can be cut back to encourage more compact growth. Pruning helps to promote healthy growth and can prevent the plant from becoming too large for its space."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Plains Yucca","description":"Yucca campestris, the plains yucca, is a species in the family Asparagaceae, endemic to the \"panhandle\" region of northwestern Texas.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Plains Yucca"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Yucca campestris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15969,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Abelmoschus esculentus, commonly known as okra, requires consistent moisture for optimal growth. During the growing season, ensure that the soil remains evenly moist, but not waterlogged, as this can lead to root rot. Water the plant deeply at least once a week, or more frequently during hot, dry spells. Applying a layer of mulch around the base can help retain soil moisture and reduce watering frequency. It is crucial to water the plant at its base to prevent wetting the foliage, which can lead to fungal diseases. Always check the top inch of soil before watering to determine if it feels dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Abelmoschus esculentus thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. A warm, sunny location is ideal, as this plant is heat-tolerant and flourishes in higher temperatures. Insufficient sunlight may result in stunted growth and reduced pod production. For gardeners in cooler climates, growing okra in containers that can be moved to the sunniest spots or using row covers can help maximize sunlight exposure. Paying attention to sunlight requirements helps ensure the plant utilizes its full potential for growth and pod yield."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Abelmoschus esculentus involves removing any diseased, damaged, or dead leaves throughout the growing season to promote healthy growth. Early in the season, selective pruning of the plant's lower leaves can improve air circulation and reduce the risk of fungal infections. Once the plant starts to produce a significant amount of pods, you may trim some of the stems to encourage further branching and more prolific pod production. Be cautious not to over-prune; maintaining ample foliage is essential for photosynthesis and overall plant health. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Okra","description":"Okra or okro (US: /ˈoʊkrə/ or UK: /ˈɒkrə/), known in many English-speaking countries as ladies' fingers or ochro, is a flowering plant in the mallow family. It is valued for its edible green seed pods. The geographical origin of okra is disputed, with supporters of West African, Ethiopian, and South Asian origins. The plant is cultivated in tropical, subtropical and warm temperate regions around the world.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Africa","Middle East","South Asia"],"other_name":["Okra"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Abelmoschus esculentus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14275,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agaricus xanthodermus, commonly known as the yellow-staining mushroom, is not typically cultivated for ornamental or consumption purposes due to its toxic nature. This will not only tidy the plant but also help to alleviate any potential issues with mold or pests. Avoid cutting into older, woody growth as proteas do not regenerate from such areas readily. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent damaging the plant or introducing diseases, and try to prune during dry weather conditions to help reduce the risk of infections."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Common Ground Sugarbush","description":"Protea acaulos (common ground sugarbush) is a flowering plant found in western Cape Province, South Africa. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15472,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cotinus coggygria prefers moderate watering. During the first year, water regularly to help establish the roots, especially during dry spells. Once established, it is relatively drought-tolerant and only requires watering during prolonged dry periods. Ensure the soil dries out between waterings to prevent root rot. Over-watering can be detrimental, so always check soil moisture before watering again. In pots, ensure good drainage to avoid waterlogging. In general, less frequent watering is required if the plant is grown in cooler areas compared to hotter regions where increased watering might be necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cotinus coggygria thrives in full sun to partial shade, with full sun conditions yielding the best leaf color and flowering. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to promote vibrant foliage colors and abundant blooms. While it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade may cause leggy growth and reduced flowering. In hotter regions, a site with some afternoon shade can protect the plant from intense sun stress. Ensure the planting location has good air circulation and is not overshadowed by larger trees."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cotinus coggygria is generally done to maintain shape, remove deadwood, and encourage bushier growth. Late winter or early spring is the best time for pruning before new growth starts. Lightly prune back any dead or damaged branches. For a bushier shrub, prune back harder; however, this might reduce flowering for the season. Alternatively, if you prefer larger blooms, allow the plant to grow more freely and only remove the necessary weak or crossing branches. Regular pruning can also help control the size of the shrub if space is limited."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Smokebush","description":"Cotinus coggygria, syn. Rhus cotinus, the European smoketree, Eurasian smoketree, smoke tree, smoke bush, or dyer's sumach is a species of flowering plant in the family Anacardiaceae, native to a large area from southern Europe, east across central Asia and the Himalayas to northern China.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Purple"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southern Europe","Central Asia","China"],"other_name":["Smokebush"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot","Stem canker","Verticillium wilt"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Cotinus coggygria"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It thrives in conditions where the soil does not dry out completely, especially during its growing season in spring and early summer. Water the plant as soon as the top inch of soil feels dry, ensuring that the soil is kept evenly moist but not waterlogged, which could lead to root rot. Protecting the plant from intense midday sun will support its growth and flowering, maintaining its vibrant foliage and robust structure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Caulophyllum giganteum is generally minimal. It involves the removal of dead or damaged leaves to maintain the plant's appearance and health. This should be done in early spring to allow for new growth to develop unimpeded. After the flowering period, spent flower stalks can be cut back to promote tidiness and direct the plant's energy towards leaf and root development. Ensure tools are clean to prevent the spread of disease. Since the plant can self-seed, controlling seed pods may be necessary if unwanted spread is a concern."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"early blue cohosh","description":"Caulophyllum giganteum, the northern blue cohosh, is a species of flowering plant in the barberry family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14185,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Chrysothrix candelaris, commonly known as the sulphur dust lichen, typically requires minimal watering as it thrives in natural habitats where moisture is primarily derived from rain or humidity. In cultivation or when used ornamentally, it’s important to mimic these conditions. Therefore, ensure the lichen is kept in a well-humidified environment and allow water from occasional mists or rains to suffice. Avoid overwatering or soaking the lichen, which may lead to rot or deterioration. Typical indoor humidity should be enough if supplemented with occasional spritzing."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chrysothrix candelaris usually thrives in shaded to partially shaded environments. It naturally grows on surfaces such as tree bark and rocks where sunlight is filtered. When cultivating this lichen, it is best to provide conditions that replicate its natural habitat—avoid full, direct sunlight as this may damage it or dry it out excessively. Ideally, place it in a location where it receives indirect light or dappled sunlight to maintain its vibrant yellow coloring and overall health. Suitable light conditions are crucial for optimal growth and longevity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not traditionally applied to Chrysothrix candelaris since it does not grow in a form that needs shaping or size control like many vascular plants. However, occasionally removing any visible detritus, such as dead material or debris, can keep the lichen looking its best. If used for decorative purposes, simply maintain its environment rather than the lichen itself. Handle carefully to avoid damage as the lichen is delicate, often needing only gentle care by cleaning any accumulating dust with a soft brush or gentle air blow."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"gold dust lichen","description":"Chrysothrix candelaris, commonly known as the mustard powder lichen or gold dust lichen, is a species of lichen in the family Chrysotrichaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14380,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ruellia humilis, also known as wild petunia, prefers moderate watering. It is quite drought-tolerant once established, but regular watering is necessary during the initial growth phase. Ensure that the soil is well-draining to prevent root rot. Water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. During hot, dry periods, you may need to water weekly, but in cooler, wetter months, the plant will require less frequent watering. Be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to waterlogged soil and poor plant health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ruellia humilis thrives in full sun, which promotes the healthiest growth and most abundant blooming. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. Although it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade can lead to reduced flowering and a leggy appearance. In extremely hot regions, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. Ensure the planting location provides ample sunlight but be mindful of potential overexposure or shade from taller plants or structures nearby. Full sun will ensure vibrant flowers and a compact shape."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ruellia humilis should be done primarily in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems to maintain plant health and aesthetics. Light deadheading, or removal of spent blooms, can encourage more blooms throughout the growing season, although the plant is fairly self-cleaning. You can also prune back leggy stems to promote a fuller, bushier growth habit. Regular maintenance pruning helps keep the plant tidy and encourages robust flowering by stimulating new growth. Ensure your pruning tools are clean and sharp to avoid damaging the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"hairy ruellia","description":"Ruellia humilis (wild petunia, fringeleaf wild petunia, hairy petunia, low wild petunia) is a species of flowering plant in the Acanthaceae, the acanthus family. Be sure to use sterilized pruning shears to prevent disease transmission. Minimal pruning is needed otherwise throughout the year."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"woolly paperflower","description":"Psilostrophe tagetina is a flowering plant in the daisy family known by the common name woolly paperflower . {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14481,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sporobolus heterolepis, also known as Prairie Dropseed, requires moderate watering, especially during the establishment phase. Once established, it is drought-tolerant and should be watered infrequently. Allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering should be avoided as it may lead to root rot. In periods of extended drought, water deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth. In general, this plant thrives in well-drained soil conditions and does not appreciate overly wet or soggy soil conditions, which can be detrimental to its health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sporobolus heterolepis thrives in full sun conditions, needing at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. This exposure helps it to grow lush and vibrant, contributing to its well-known fine-textured appearance. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun is ideal for optimum growth and flowering. Less sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced overall vigor. It is important that this plant receives sufficient light to develop its characteristic arching leaves and airy flower panicles, which are most pronounced in bright, sunny environments."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sporobolus heterolepis is primarily done to maintain its appearance and health. Pruning should be done in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Cut the grass back to a few inches above the ground. This allows fresh, new growth to emerge vigorously. Removal of dead or damaged foliage can also help prevent diseases and promote healthy growth. Light pruning in summer can also be done to maintain the desired shape and size. It's generally low maintenance but responds well to this simple clean-up."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"prairie dropseed","description":"Sporobolus heterolepis, commonly known as prairie dropseed, is a species of prairie grass native to the tallgrass and mixed grass prairies of central North America from Texas to southern Canada. It is also found further east, all the way to the Atlantic coast of the United States and Canada, but is much less common beyond the Great Plains and is restricted to specialized habitats. It is found in 24 states and 4 Canadian provinces.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pinkish","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["prairie dropseed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Sporobolus heterolepis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the site is not only sunny but also has enough open space to accommodate the tree's eventual height and spread."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cedrus atlantica should primarily focus on removing dead or diseased branches, best done during the late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Care should be taken to maintain the tree's natural shape while ensuring interior branches receive sufficient light and air. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the tree and stunt its growth. Light trimming can also be done to remove crossing branches or to shape the tree modestly as it grows."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Atlas cedar","description":"Cedrus atlantica, the Atlas cedar, is a cedar native to the Atlas Mountains of Morocco (Middle Atlas, High Atlas), to the Rif, and to the Tell Atlas in Algeria. It prefers well-draining soil, so water it sparingly to prevent root rot, especially in humid climates. During the growing season (spring and summer), water the plant deeply but allow the soil to dry out between waterings. Reduce watering frequency during the cooler months (fall and winter), ensuring the plant receives just enough moisture to keep the soil from completely drying out. It's essential to observe the plant's response to watering and adjust according to seasonal rainfall and temperature changes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"For optimal growth, Abutilon incanum requires plenty of sunlight. It thrives best in full sun to partial shade, making it adaptable to various outdoor conditions. In areas with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. If grown indoors, place the plant in a bright location with indirect sunlight, such as near a south-facing window. The plant's tolerance for drought and sun exposure makes it a suitable choice for xeriscaping and gardens in arid regions. Ensure it receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight for robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Abutilon incanum is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to promote air circulation and light penetration throughout the plant. You can also trim back leggy or overgrown stems to encourage bushier growth. Using sharp, clean pruning shears, make cuts just above a leaf node or bud to stimulate new growth. Regular pruning will help control the size of the plant and maintain a neat appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pelotazo","description":"Abutilon icanum, also known as hoary abutilon, pelotazo, pelotazo chico, tronadora, and maʻo (Hawaiʻi), is a shrub widespread throughout the arid, warm regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico as well as Hawaiʻi.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["pelotazo"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Abutilon incanum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14880,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vaccinium myrtillus, commonly known as bilberry, prefers well-drained, acidic soil and requires consistent moisture, especially during the growing season. It is important to water the plant regularly to keep the soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure good drainage in the pot or garden bed. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant is dormant. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and maintain a stable soil temperature. Pay attention to rainfall patterns and adjust watering as needed to prevent the soil from drying out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vaccinium myrtillus thrives in partial shade to full sun conditions. However, in hotter climates, it benefits from some afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorch and to keep the plant healthy. Ideally, it should receive about 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In areas with intense sunlight, providing a slight shade or dappled light, especially in the peak afternoon hours, can help reduce stress on the plant. Ensuring the plant receives adequate light will help produce a good yield of berries and maintain robust growth. Regular checks should ensure that its sunlight needs are being met without overexposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vaccinium myrtillus is typically done in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Removing dead, diseased, or damaged branches is essential to maintain the plant's health and improve air circulation. Light pruning can encourage more prolific fruiting by allowing more sunlight to reach all parts of the plant. Remove any older, less productive stems to stimulate new growth and increase berry production. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the plant and reduce yield. Regular maintenance and thinning of the plant will promote a healthier shrub with better berry output."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"common bilberry","description":"Vaccinium myrtillus is a species of shrub with edible fruit of blue color, commonly called \"bilberry\", \"wimberry\", \"whortleberry\", or European blueberry. It has much in common with the American blueberry (Vaccinium cyanococcus). It is more precisely called common bilberry or blue whortleberry, to distinguish it from other Vaccinium relatives. Regional names include blaeberry, hurtleberry, huckleberry, wimberry, whinberry, winberry, and fraughan.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue, Black\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["common bilberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Vaccinium myrtillus"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15473,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Chamaecyparis obtusa, commonly known as Hinoki Cypress, requires a careful watering regimen to thrive. It's important to keep the soil consistently moist but not soggy. Water the plant deeply when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During the hotter months, you might need to water more frequently, while in cooler months, reduce the watering schedule slightly to prevent root rot. Consistent humidity is beneficial, so consider misting or using a pebble tray if the indoor air is very dry. Ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to avoid water stagnation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chamaecyparis obtusa thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate full sun in cooler climates but needs protection from the harsh afternoon sun in hotter areas, which can scorch its foliage. Ideally, position the plant where it can receive morning sun and afternoon shade. If grown indoors, place it near a window with filtered light. While it can adapt to lower light conditions, the foliage may lose its vibrant color. Therefore, ensure it gets adequate light to maintain its lush, green appearance. Adjust its position seasonally to match changing sunlight patterns. "},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Chamaecyparis obtusa is essential to maintain its shape and health. The best time to prune is in late winter to early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches first. It's crucial to prune back to a branch junction or bud to stimulate new growth. Avoid cutting into the older, brown wood as it may not re-sprout. Pruning shears should be sharp and clean to make precise cuts and prevent disease. Regular trimming can help maintain the desired size and shape, encouraging denser foliage and healthier overall growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hinoki cypress","description":"Chamaecyparis obtusa (Japanese cypress, hinoki cypress or hinoki; Japanese: 檜 or 桧, hinoki) is a species of cypress native to central Japan.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Japan"],"other_name":["Hinoki cypress"],"pest_susceptibility":["Canker","Heart rot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Chamaecyparis obtusa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In hotter regions, a bit of afternoon shade may help prevent leaf scorch but make sure not to overcompensate with shade. Ensuring sufficient sunlight helps the plant maintain its vibrant blooms and healthy foliage throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lupinus angustifolius is relatively simple, primarily focusing on deadheading and managing plant shape. After the plant flowers, remove any spent blooms to encourage further blooming and prevent seed setting, which can exhaust the plant's resources. Additionally, trim back any damaged or diseased foliage to maintain overall plant health. At the end of the growing season, you can cut back the entire plant to the base to prepare it for dormancy. Pruning not only keeps the plant looking tidy but also promotes healthier growth in the subsequent season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Narrow-leaved Lupine","description":"Lupinus angustifolius is a species of lupin known by many common names, including narrowleaf lupin, narrow-leaved lupin and blue lupin.
